definition[0]: a piece of equipment for catching animals
example[0]: The only way to catch mice is to set a trap.
example[1]: He stepped into a bear trap covered in snow.
definition[1]: a clever trick that is used to catch someone or to make them do or say something that they did not intend to
example[2]: Police had set a trap for hooligans at the match.
example[3]: Mr Smith has walked straight into a trap laid by the Tories.
definition[2]: an unpleasant or difficult situation that is difficult to escape from
example[4]: Amanda felt that marriage was a trap.
example[5]: people caught in the unemployment trap
definition[3]: a vehicle with two wheels, pulled by a horse
definition[5]: a special gate from which a greyhound is set free at the beginning of a race
definition[6]: to prevent someone from escaping from somewhere, especially a dangerous place
example[7]: The building collapsed, trapping dozens of people in the rubble.
example[8]: There’s no way out! We’re trapped!
explanation[0]: Trap is often passive in this meaning
definition[7]: to catch an animal or bird using a trap
definition[8]: to catch someone by forcing them into a place from which they cannot escape
example[9]: The police trapped the terrorists at a roadblock.
definition[9]: to trick someone so that you make them do or say something that they did not intend to
example[10]: I was trapped into signing a confession.
definition[10]: to get a part of your body crushed between two objects
example[11]: Mind you don’t trap your fingers in the door.
definition[11]: to prevent something such as gas or water from getting away
example[13]: solar panels that trap the sun’s heat
